WRITING.TEXT: I had Peter Pan syndrome like a mf last semester. Days blur by. If the days feel the same try to break out of your comfort zone and do and try new things
Hell yes dude. That edited ad with Wings and Taylor talking over it had my crying. Taylor needs to get a clean title Mustang; sell him your yote!
If it's not my mom or work I will literally decline and text the person

Lmao everyone uses this as a default defense when you tell people you don #8217;t want kids. I agree with you I was a reckless child. Little snot rockets can be annoying. I wanted kids for a while but the more and more I think about it, freedom gt;kids

Just got put on antidepressants for the second time about a week ago. It takes a few weeks for your body to get used to; especially the first few days when you up the dosage it feels like you have the stomach flu. 3-4 weeks you #8217;ll notice results. Hang in there, whatever you #8217;re going through it #8217;ll get better. Life can be stressful and a couple months ago there was a trend going around saying, #8220;yeah antidepressants and medications are good but have you tried: #8221; Sometimes you try everything and nothing works so you get medicated. Don #8217;t be ashamed and stick to your prescription!!

Depending on whether or not you have a set budget or if money isn't an issue might as well go ahead and get the best hardware so you don't have to constantly upgrade. I've heard mixed reviews on the 20xx series cards, the 2060 in particular, a lot of people have already had their cards go bad or were defective. But if you buy new you get a warranty. If you're thinking about getting a new card I'd just go with a 2060. Mass-produced technology parts aren't all going to come out perfect and if you're looking at getting a 1660Ti might as well spend the extra $70 for a card that performs about 20% better according to userbenchmark

I read the rules and guidelines but couldn't find what I was looking for on whether or not replies needed to be titled or not so feel free to reply with any feedback or things I need to edit :) Shamus had been walking through the Eternal Garden for a while now, exploring the different features it had to offer: the bright, green vegetation, the fully blossomed colorful flowers, and the diverse species of animals that lived in the Garden. He lived in a village in the Garden in a nice valley but had never gotten the opportunity to explore the Garden in depth. Shamus usually stayed close to his village since he was still a growing teen. He had been exploring for a few hours and had just walked through a vibrant forest with large maple trees with a creek that slivered through the forest. Though seeing many small animals and hearing many birds in the forest, as Shamus reached the border he neglected the wildlife becoming distant as he reached the edge of the forest into a new area of the Garden. Tired and looking to take a break, Shamus turned a corner behind a small stone wall and sat down on a tree stump. He noticed this area was a bit dark and eerie compared to the rest of the Garden he had explored so far. Not eating in a while, he noticed deep blue mushrooms growing on both the grass and in the stump right beside him. Feeling hungry, Shamus was instantly intrigued by these mushrooms. He plucked one from the tree stump and held it in his hand. The mushroom was a few inches long and the head was quite a few inches wide; the fungi taking up the entirety of his palm. He popped it in his mouth and chewed. The dry, bitter taste was not satisfying, but there was nothing else to eat. Shamus chewed up the mushroom, swallowed it, and was surprisingly full. He decided to sit on the stump for a little while longer before continuing his exploration throughout the Garden. All of a sudden, an uneasy feeling in his stomach and sensed a different feeling he had never felt before. This induced Shamus into a panic, as he quickly stood up and took a few steps forward from behind the stone wall to see where he should walk next. But this feeling was so overwhelming he forgot which direction he had come from. As he turned around, he noticed a thick vine moving up the stone wall. He followed the vine up the wall, only to be looking up at the face of an extremely frightening creature; a fierce monster with a disfigured alicorn, horns, and deep, red eyes gazing right back at Shamus. This beast had such large, sharp teeth and not all of them fit in its mouth with the mouth being fully closed. Sensing Shamus's fear, one foot of this monstrosity began to slink toward Shamus. Then another foot. This beast had come off of the wall entirely at this point and stood. This monstrosity was twice as tall as Shamus and very lean. Under his chin was a bunch of smooth, clean gray fur. Caught in a daze, Shamus took a rapid glance around him and noticed the many graves that had been there for hundreds of years and immediately knew he was in a bad place of the Garden and needed to escape. Shamus began to run. The beast behind him let out a deep roar that echoed throughout the surrounding areas and sent flocks of birds to retreat. Shamus took off in the direction he was facing, an area of light brush and smaller trees, feeling the thumps in the ground of the beast chasing after him. Dodging and weaving around fallen trees and trunks with the beast in toe, Shamus's breathing became heavy and he was running out of energy, his mouth parched from dehydration. But he kept running as fast as he can. The beast swatted at Shamus from behind and caught a hold of his jacket, dragging Shamus closer to him. He wrapped his claws around Shamus and suspended him 10 feet in the air, right in front of his muzzle. Looking death in the face, Shamus felt the heavy exhales of the beast, encumbering him with humid bursts of gases exhausted by the beast. For being small and agile, Shamus was able to slip out of his thick wool jacket and landed on the ground, with his hat bouncing on the ground right beside him. Shamus took off again, in the distance he heard lots of water movement and realized he was coming to the edge of a cliff. To his right, he noticed a river turning into a waterfall. To his left, he caught a glimpse of a valley with a river where the waterfall was pouring into. With the beast right behind him, he knew he had to evade this devilish freak, and there was only one way to do that: jump. With the beast right behind him, Shamus took a few long lunges before throwing himself off the cliff. He could hear the beast's heavy breathing as if it was an arm's length away, which it was. As he leaped off the cliff, the beast swatted at Shamus one more time but wasn't willing to jump after him. On the way down, Shamus saw his village he lived in. A 60 foot drop into the river knocked the wind out of Shamus, and he was unable to function properly. He was just being carried by the current at this point and eventually drifted close to a river bank when he noticed an arm catch onto him and pull him out of the water. He passed out following this. After coming to, he was very weak and in a bed. His grandmother Aileen asked where he had been. He told her what happened, and she replied that it was all nonsense. He had just eaten poisonous mushrooms and had a bad experience because he took the mushrooms alone and it was his first time so he didn't know how to react. Aileen went on to explain that the Eternal Forest is a utopia. There are small villages and the Garden has plenty of resources that never run out. Everyone is safe in the Garden. Everyone is at peace. Aileen told Shamus he was going to be okay, handing him a cup of water, which Shamus gulped down quickly from having a parched mouth and being dehydrated. She advised him to not go alone the next time he wanted to explore the Garden. Nobody has found the edge of the Garden; there was much more to explore. Shamus was eager to go delve deeper into the Garden in a different area, but decided to get some rest for now.

Just remember that conversation is a two-way street and there #8217;s so many people you can converse with. Sometimes the conversation with someone will be dry because they can #8217;t hold a conversation. The goal is to just keep the conversation rolling. If you don #8217;t know what to say try to observe your surroundings and comment on it or ask a question about something in or around the establishment Bottom line some people you connect with and some people you don #8217;t. A little liquid courage helps too

You #8217;re definitely overthinking and shouldn #8217;t have this mindset. It #8217;s hard for me too but at the same time just be yourself. The goal isn #8217;t to attract everyone, it #8217;s to attract the people that are right for you

Going to the gym was hard for me because I #8217;m a big dude but don #8217;t lift heavy because I just got into working out. At first I felt like people were staring at me and judging me but when I #8217;d actually take a break or finish a set I #8217;d look around and notice nobody gave a fuck as to what I was doing. Observe your surroundings when you start to get anxious and you #8217;ll notice everyone is minding their own business. If there #8217;s one person in the place staring at you that #8217;s their problem if they want to judge you. They #8217;re wasting their own time looking you up and down while everyone else is going about their lives
Very niche but I love it!

WRITING.TITLE: I keep slipping up and don #8217;t know how to stop
WRITING.TEXT: This semester of college has been a shit show for me. I self harmed for the first time in January, then a couple more times in a February, then again in March, and then again on Sunday night I definitely have a drinking problem, and school gives me a lot of anxiety and anticipation because I don #8217;t know how well I #8217;m going to end up doing. I like getting drunk to pass the time. Sometimes I get too drunk and look in the mirror and just hate what I see, have a small mental breakdown/panic attack, and I #8217;ll cut myself to feel better. It gives me this high that ends my attack I saw a psychiatrist about 6 weeks ago and was prescribed antidepressants and I #8217;m seeing a therapist in May. I #8217;m still young and live with my mom back home and she knows I #8217;ve been a bit depressed but she has no idea what #8217;s really been going on. My sister struggled with self harm when we were both in high school and my mom was sympathetic about it, but I don #8217;t want her to know it #8217;s a struggle another one of her kids is going through When I cut, alcohol is involved. If anyone has any advice on how to cut drinking and stop cutting please comment, this shit is getting scary, my antidepressants aren #8217;t helping, and I just want to feel better
